awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Improved Vehicle Autonomy in Geophysical Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
Networks of autonomous underwater and surface vehicles (AUVs and ASVs) allow direct and continuous monitoring of the ocean. New deployment strategies are needed to obtain maximum coverage from a relatively small number of vessels. This will require better understanding of the structures controlling transport in geophysical flows such as ocean currents. New results show that AUV/ASV motion planning and adaptive sampling strategies are improved by incorporating models of ocean current dynamics. However, these currents change continually and apparently unpredictably, and this makes it highly challenging to take full advantage. The goals of this project are to better understand the dynamics of the dominant structures in ocean currents, and to explore their impact on AUV/ASV autonomy. Additionally, this work will produce robust motion control strategies for both single vehicles and teams of vehicles, to track desired structure boundaries, while leveraging the environmental dynamics to prolong operational lifespan. 

In pursuit of the project goals, the research objectives are to: 1) identify and evaluate key kinematic features that control transport in oceanic surface flows of greatest relevance to autonomous vehicle navigation and control, 2) develop a general mathematical and control framework for teams of autonomous vehicles that leverages key transport controlling features in oceanic flows for improved navigation and monitoring of dynamic and uncertain environments, and 3) apply the control framework to the tracking of salt wedge fronts using the WHOI Jetyaks to establish the transition from the laboratory to the ocean. This work has a significant experimental component that leverages the PIs' existing research infrastructure.  The work addresses the theoretical and experimental challenges needed to develop a general mathematical and control framework for applying geophysical fluid dynamics to the development of novel planning, navigation, and control strategies for individual and networked teams of autonomous vehicles.

por.por_cntn:
The project combined computational, experimental and theoretical approaches to improved sensing and control of autonomous objects in complex fluid flows. At large scales, the project treated autonomous aquatic vehicles in geophysical-scale flows, such as oceans. This work was developed along two paths: smaller  boats typical of those used as ocean sensors or in sensor networks, possessing active control; and massive Marine Permaculture Arrays, up to 1 square kilometer in size, with largely passive control. At micro scales, the project used similar techniques, but with the added capability of magnetic control. This was done as a means of studying the 3D problem as a model in the laboratory.

Several robust re-usable numerical tools were developed and applied, including a simulation code for study of vehicle shape interaction with complex 3D flows, a camera-based flow mapper, codes for optimal vehicle control, codes for extracting controlling features in flows, codes for data analysis and visualization and finally, codes for applying machine learning to flow feature based control. The outcomes from the project are:

1. Laboratory autonomous boats: We have performed a suite of experiments using an in-house flow tanks designed and built for this project. Using two simple pumps to create single and double gyre flows and an overhead camera to capture flow maps on which particle imaging velocimetry (PIV) and particle tracking velocimetry (PTV) were applied. An autonomous dual motor boat was then deployed in the tank, supported by a separate sensing system and control algorithm. We then validated that optimal paths were correlated with exploiting flow features known as Lagrangian Coherent Structures (LCS). Finally, in a collaboration with The Climate Foundation (Woods Hole, MA) we have built, modeled and tested a design for control of massive (1 square kilometer) floating kelp forests (Marine Permaculture Arrays or MPAs). This work was a winner of the global Blue Economy Challenge.

Flow structure FTLE codes: Vehicle autonomy in this project is achieved by applying control that is optimized by leveraging robust fluid flow structures. We thus developed, validated and tested a finite-time Lyapunov exponent (FTLE) based identifier of LCS, those persistent flow features used to attract or repel vehicles. Our FTLE codes work on both models and data.

Magnetic sensing and control: To extend this project to 3D vehicle motion, we used two proxies; the first proxy is based on 3D numerical simulation using the PARIS code, described below. The second is a 2D and 3D experimental platform for magnetic sensing and control of model vehicles. In particular, we have developed a suite of laboratory devices and computational tools and models to perform the following: (i) 2D magnetic (not visual) sensing of model vehicle location; (ii) robust visual characterization of model vehicle shap; (iii) 3D visual model vehicle location; and (iv) 2D magnetic control to steer model vehicles magnetically.

PARIS: Direct Numerical Simulation code for flow-shape effects: We have developed a direct numerical simulation method, within the framework of a multi-phase Navier-Stokes code known as Paris, to perform numerical experiments on realistic, extended inertial objects with shape, finite size and density. Codes were validated on complex 3D ows and results informed theoretical work, specically the role of a vehicle's shape on its trajectory in a given flow field.

Machine Learning applied to ow structures for vehicle control: We have developed, validated and tested an Echo State neural network based framework for modeling of complex geophysical flows in order to have robust flow models when sensing data is sparse, overly noisy or missing.

The results obtained from this project include a wide range of computational tools and algorithms for flow sensing, flow structure identication, flow-structure modeling, magnetic control and magnetic sensing, all of which are generally applicable to the efficient control of vehicles in flow fields.

In addition, a number of experimental devices and laboratory platforms created for this project are still in use at the Cooper Union, including a 3D visual sensing and magnetic control tank (no flow), a 2D magnetic sensing and control device (no flkow) and a 2 meter flow tank with flow sensing and a controllable boat.

Outcomes from the research project were presented at conferences and workshops, and were published in refereed scientic journals and conference proceedings including Robotics Research (Springer) and Computer Physics Communications (Elsevier).

The project supported 14 undergraduate students, 1 masters student, and a high school student; to date 4 of the undergraduates have continued with graduate programs in related areas. The students learned and used skills, including theoretical and computational methods, reading and understanding the existing scientic literature, writing, and presenting their work.
